importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date the news article was published, indicating the most current update on the flooding crisis in Mexico.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding and related deaths occurred during the last week, establishing the temporal scope of the disaster.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing.
Veracruz confirmed 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro one.
43 people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops have been deployed, including the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard.
About 100,000 houses have been affected, with some near rivers effectively destroyed.
The heavy rainfall was linked to the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond.
The heaviest rains were recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Nearly 400 repair workers restored over 80% of electricity supply for around 263,000 affected users.
President Claudia Sheinbaum acknowledged that no prior meteorological warnings predicted the magnitude of rainfall.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused severe flooding across five Mexican states, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The hardest-hit areas were Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths), with significant numbers of missing persons. The Mexican military, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, has been deployed to deliver aid, especially in landslides-affected and road-blocked areas. Over 100,000 homes were damaged, and nearly 263,000 households lost electricity. The government acknowledged that no prior meteorological warnings predicted the intensity of the rainfall, raising questions about early warning systems in Mexico.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
